messages.message:
:githubparrot: Github Repo access audit for SOC2
hi, everybody thanks so much for your help with enabling SSO authentication to instabase Github Org :pray: now let's continue the fun :fun:
As part of SOC2 compliance we need to make sure our production source code access is properly set and the release control is in place to reinforce code review before merging to release branches, we need some of your help to gather our current status on this, below is a google sheet with all of the code repos under instabase org `if you happen to be on charge of any of our git repo, can you take a minute to help us fill in some of the details as much as you can please?`
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1jCggU1TShkf0ur3lMUl9rAeRTZsJLc6utatI0hDLfuY/edit?usp=sharing

questions feel free to drop in <#C035SLYCJ9X|> :pray:

@shiqi can you explain quickly what each column mean? for example, “production-related” - means that is the repo a part of the instabase release?  what makes a repo “team access audited”? what counts as “branch protection”?

yes, sorry for the confusion
`production related`: if the code in this repo will be included as part of instabase product to be shipped to customer
`team access audited` : go to https://github.com/instabase/<REPO_NAME>/settings/access to verify all teams have proper access (read, write, admin...) set
`branch protection`: basically means if the release branch (defined in release branch name column) is set to protected by code review requirement and/or CI status (more details here (https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/defining-the-mergeability-of-pull-requests/about-protected-branches))
also, it is OK if we don't have anything set up yet or we don't know, we just want to get a sense of where we are and follow up by taking actions to fill the gap in prepare for SOC2
thanks. so if a repo is not a part of a release (if `production related` is `no`), there’s no need to fill out `release branch name` and `branch protection` i assume?
cc @Hari here too, and @Balaram for solution eng repos
correct, ideally we want to set up branch protection regardless because it is good engineering practice but for this audit we will only focus on the production related repos
